quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: And every time I point out the contradiction, they just go quiet.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and silence isn’t good enough when it comes to your safety.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Exactly. Silence just proves they’re avoiding accountability.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I’ve told them that I need answers in writing, not silence.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But you see how I’m always the one having to push for this?

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I do, and I know it’s exhausting for you.

contradictions.issue: Police silence when contradictions raised vs. advocate admits silence not acceptable but no escalation outcome

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: It’s like I have to keep proving the same point over and over, and nothing changes.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and that’s not fair on you.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: That’s not support, that’s me being worn down.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand, and I don’t want you to feel that way.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But it’s what’s happening. I feel like they’re just waiting for me to give up.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I hear you. I’ll keep pressing so that doesn’t happen.

contradictions.issue: Victim reports being worn down by repetition vs. advocate acknowledges but offers no systemic fix

timeline_hooks.link: Pattern of institutional erosion of victim resilience

timeline_hooks.ref: waiting for me to give up

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: If I didn’t keep on at you, none of this would even be chased.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I would still be chasing, Ben, but I understand it feels like that.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Feels like it? It is that. I’m doing the work you should be doing.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I am doing the work, but I know you don’t see the results yet.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Results matter when it’s my safety at risk.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I do understand that, and I’ll keep pressing.

contradictions.issue: Victim asserts advocate not doing their role; advocate insists she is but results absent

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: When I raise the same issues, I’m treated like I’m difficult, instead of them fixing the problem.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: That’s not how it should be, Ben. You have every right to raise issues.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But it is how it is. I get labelled instead of supported.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I don’t label you, but I can see how it comes across when they don’t respond properly.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: It’s not just how it comes across, it’s what’s happening. They’re rewriting what’s real.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand. That’s why I keep pushing for clarity in writing.

contradictions.issue: Victim labelled difficult vs. advocate says not by her but concedes systemic misrepresentation

timeline_hooks.link: Evidence of gaslighting and erasure tactics

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: It’s like they’re writing a story where I’m the problem, instead of recording what’s actually happened.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and I’ve told them that records have to reflect accurately, not opinions.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But if those records are wrong, they’ll be used against me later.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: That’s why I’ve asked for corrections to be made when errors are spotted.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: I shouldn’t need you to ask, they should just record it right first time.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I agree, it should be right the first time.

contradictions.issue: Victim perceives records rewritten to frame him; advocate concedes errors but frames as fixable instead of systemic

timeline_hooks.ref: risk of misuse of wrong records

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: And if they’re already twisting records now, what happens in court later?

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: That’s why it’s important to keep everything documented, so we can challenge it if needed.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But they’re the ones holding the official file, not me.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and that’s why I keep a record on my side as well, to compare.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Still, it feels like the odds are stacked against me.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand. It does feel very unfair.

contradictions.issue: Victim warns twisted records risk court misuse; advocate frames documentation as protection but systemic power imbalance remains

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: It’s like they already decided I’m the problem before even looking at the evidence.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and that’s why I’ve said to them the evidence has to be central, not assumptions.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But when evidence disappears, assumptions win.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: That’s true, and I keep challenging them on that point.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Feels like no matter what I give them, it’ll vanish or be ignored.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand, Ben. That’s why I’ll keep checking and re-checking what they log.

contradictions.issue: Victim states bias against him; evidence disappears vs. advocate insists she challenges but acknowledges risk

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: What’s the point of me giving evidence if it just disappears into a black hole?

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: The point is it builds a record, even if they mishandle it, it still shows you’ve done your part.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But I’m the one at risk, not them. A record doesn’t protect me.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I agree, it doesn’t keep you safe in the moment, but it matters for accountability later.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Later doesn’t help me if something happens now.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and that’s why I’ll keep pressing them on immediate safety as well.

contradictions.issue: Advocate frames evidence as future accountability vs. victim highlights present safety risk

timeline_hooks.ref: evidence builds record but not safety

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: So if something happens to me tomorrow, the record just proves they ignored me.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Yes, and that’s why it’s vital to keep it consistent, so the failures are visible.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Visible after the fact doesn’t stop it happening.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand, Ben. I’ll keep pressing them on the urgent side too.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: It feels like I’m being left to prove they failed, instead of being protected.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and that’s not how it should be.

contradictions.issue: Victim highlights being left to prove failure vs. advocate admits this is wrong but offers no immediate remedy

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: I’ve been saying the same thing for months, but nothing changes. How is that acceptable?

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: It isn’t acceptable, Ben, and I’ve told them that too.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Then why is it still happening?

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Because the system is slow to respond, but I will continue to press them.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Slow isn’t good enough when my safety is on the line.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I agree, it isn’t good enough.

contradictions.issue: Victim asks why systemic failure persists; advocate blames 'slow system' but concedes not acceptable

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Every time I give them something, it vanishes. Then later I’m asked to prove I ever sent it.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Yes, and that’s why I’ve said to them they need to confirm receipt in writing.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But if they won’t confirm, then it’s just my word against theirs.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, which is why I’ve kept my own log to show when things were sent.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But your log isn’t official. They hold the file, not us.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: True, but if they contradict, we can show the timeline from our side.

contradictions.issue: Victim highlights evidence vanishing vs. advocate admits only secondary log exists; official file controlled by police
